title: Pell Survived Due to 9/11 Sensitivity
author: Various One Piece Community Members
theory: The theory suggests that Eiichiro Oda originally planned for Pell to die in the explosion but changed his mind due to sensitivity around the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. Since the episode aired in Japan on September 8, 2002, approximately one year after 9/11, and featured a character performing a suicide bombing on a tower, Oda and his editors may have felt it was in poor taste to keep the death. This led to Pell's survival being revealed in Episode 130.
evidence: Episode 125 aired September 8, 2002, about a year after the 9/11 attacks
The scene involves a character carrying a bomb to sacrifice themselves
Pell's survival was not shown in the immediate aftermath, suggesting a possible last-minute change
The emotional weight of the scene suggests it was meant to be a permanent death
popularity: High - widely discussed in the One Piece community
communityReception: Mixed - many fans find it plausible given the timing, but others note that Oda has never confirmed this and the theory remains speculation
counterArguments: Oda has never officially confirmed this theory
One Piece has a pattern of characters surviving seemingly fatal situations that predates this arc
The manga chapters were written before 9/11, so the story was already set
Oda may have simply wanted to avoid killing a heroic character

title: Pell's Zoan Durability Saved Him
author: One Piece Community
theory: Pell survived the explosion because Zoan-type Devil Fruit users have enhanced durability and toughness. The theory suggests that Pell threw the bomb upward to get it as high as possible while simultaneously diving downward, catching only the edge of the blast rather than taking it at point-blank range. His Zoan transformation provided enough enhanced durability to survive the injuries.
evidence: Zoan users are shown throughout the series to have enhanced physical durability
Pell could have released the bomb and dove away at the last moment
He was found injured but alive at a remote hospital, suggesting he fell from the sky
Other Zoan users survive extreme damage throughout the series
popularity: Moderate - often cited as a rationalization for the survival
communityReception: Generally accepted as the most logical in-universe explanation, though many still find the survival narratively unsatisfying
counterArguments: The explosion had a 5-kilometer blast radius and was shown as massive
The narrative framed it as a definitive sacrifice
Even with Zoan durability, surviving such an explosion seems implausible
No explanation is given in the story itself for how he survived

title: The 'Pell Effect' - Oda's Reluctance to Kill Characters
author: One Piece Community
theory: Pell's survival established what fans call the 'Pell Effect' - a pattern in One Piece where characters survive seemingly unsurvivable situations. The theory posits that Oda is fundamentally reluctant to kill characters, especially heroic ones, preferring to maintain the series' generally optimistic tone. This event set a precedent that has continued throughout the series with other fake-out deaths.
evidence: Multiple characters throughout One Piece survive apparently fatal situations
Pell's survival despite a massive explosion with no clear explanation
Oda's preference for happy endings and character redemption over permanent death
Very few major characters die in One Piece compared to other shonen series
popularity: Very High - widely acknowledged pattern in the community
communityReception: Mixed - some fans appreciate the optimistic tone, others feel it reduces dramatic stakes
counterArguments: Some significant characters do die in One Piece (Ace, Whitebeard, etc.)
The series may simply have different narrative priorities than other shonen
Death isn't the only way to create dramatic stakes
Oda may have specific narrative reasons for each survival

title: Pell Will Have Future Significance
author: Various theorists
source: One Piece forums and discussion boards
theory: Some fans theorize that Oda kept Pell alive because he plans to use the character in a significant way later in the series. His survival, while controversial, suggests he may have an important role to play in future events involving Arabasta or the broader One Piece narrative.
evidence: Oda rarely does things without purpose in his storytelling
Arabasta has been referenced multiple times post-timeskip
Pell's position as one of only five known flying Devil Fruit users could be significant
The Nefertari family has connections to the Void Century and Ancient Kingdom
communityReception: Skeptical but open - many fans would appreciate a narrative payoff for the controversial survival
counterArguments: Pell has not appeared significantly since the Arabasta arc
His survival could simply be a narrative mistake or editorial decision
Not every character needs future significance to justify survival
Years have passed with no indication of future importance

title: The Bomb's Blast Radius Was Exaggerated
author: Various fans
theory: Some fans theorize that the bomb's stated 5-kilometer blast radius was an exaggeration or estimate by Baroque Works, and the actual explosion was less powerful than claimed. This would make Pell's survival more plausible if he got far enough away and the explosion wasn't as devastating as feared.
evidence: The explosion is seen from a distance but actual damage radius is never confirmed
Baroque Works may have exaggerated the bomb's power for psychological effect
High altitude explosions dissipate differently than ground-level ones
popularity: Low - most fans don't find this compelling
communityReception: Generally rejected - undermines the dramatic stakes of the scene
counterArguments: The narrative presents the bomb as genuinely city-destroying
The visual depiction shows a massive explosion
This explanation would undermine the heroism of Pell's sacrifice
No in-story evidence supports the bomb being weaker than stated
